A. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

[40 CFR 68.155; CalARP Article 3, 2745.3]

The Risk Management Program at Growers Ice Company is designed to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of releases of anhydrous ammonia from the refrigeration process. The following is a summary of the programs, policies, and procedures in place to reduce the risk of a hazardous materials release.



The purpose of the RMP is threefold: 1.) to prevent unwanted releases of hazardous chemicals, especially into locations that could expose employees and others to serious hazards, 2.) to identify hazards associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia, and 3.) to provide procedures to minimize the risks involved with handling this material.



Growers Ice Company has implemented the RMP at the Salinas, CA facility in order to comply with regulations and to fulfill this facility's responsibility to protect its employees, equipment, property, the surrounding community, and the environment from accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.



In addition to the mandated prevention program elements listed in the RMP:

? The Growers Ice Company facility utilizes visual inspection procedures prior to startup and shutdown of on-line cooling equipment. This equipment includes compressors, condensers, and evaporation equipment as well as ice makers, vacuum coolers and air handling equipment



? General visual inspections are done throughout the day as starting or stopping of the equipment is required



? Inspections identify potential sources of problems and potential releases of ammonia.

On-site personnel, registered engineers and refrigeration contractors as required then resolve equipment corrections



? As described above, Accidental Release Prevention is a continuing ongoing process involving system inspection, emergency response program reviews and employee hazardous response training (performed yearly). All new operating technicians are trained in safety and operational safeties specific to the o

peration of the refrigeration equipment



? Business Response Procedures and Emergency Response Procedures are updated yearly.

The Business Response Plan includes the Emergency Response Procedures which are updated yearly



? Portable equipment, new to the site, is tested for operational safeties at the time of specific installation, typically at least once a year



? All ammonia refrigeration maintenance and operations personnel are required to be trained and become familiar with the company's Safety and Operational Procedures and

Emergency Response Plan (also referred to as Emergency Response Program). Regular department safety meetings with recorded employee participation are required. Records of attendance are in the main office. "Ammonia Leak' response training occurs at company safety department meetings when meetings occur, typically on a 12 times a year schedule. Yearly local community hazards response training is made available to all refrigeration on an assigned basis, work shifts and specific operations dictate actual attendance. Air Pak Training (self-contained breathing apparatus), updated fit tests, and medical qualifications are done yearly; records are maintained in the main office



? Refrigerating Engineers & Technicians Association (RETA) certified personnel are trained in safe operating practices of the basic engine rooms and refrigeration systems. Certificate of Achievement copies are maintained in employee files.



1. Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

Growers Ice Company will maintain a release prevention program to eliminate or minimize any releases. The program will include regular inspections, monitoring equipment and logging conditions, scheduled maintenance, and operator training. There is a program to analyze releases for ways to prevent a similar future release, see Incident Investigation Forms. A Risk

Management Program, which includes accident prevention procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system, is mainta

ined on-site along with this RMP.



The ammonia refrigeration system has specific safety procedures to prevent a release.

Operators and mechanics are trained for safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system. They are also trained in emergency response procedures in the event of an ammonia release. There are emergency shut off switches for shutting down the system. Personnel will automatically be notified if any detector exceeds set point. Monitoring is 24 hours a day. An emergency control box and diffusion tank allows system pressure to be relieved manually. Relief valves at the 1140 Meeks St. facility are tied to an ammonia diffusion tank to prevent high pressure releases to ambient.



On-site personnel provide initial emergency response. On-site personnel will make a preliminary assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response. First response may include emergency equipment shutdown, system isolation, or controlled operation such as pump down to prevent or reduce an offsite release. 



No emergency operations will be performed that are beyond the capabilities of the operators or other on-site personnel and for releases above an ammonia concentration of 300 ppm.



Local fire and police departments with mutual aid response will provide emergency response for a major release event. The refrigeration contractors would also be on-call to provide emergency response.



Emergency response training will be conducted yearly for current employees and as required for new employees. Records will be kept of all training performed at the site for a minimum of five (5) years.



2. Description of Stationary Source and Substance Handled



Purpose

To provide the owner, operator and employees a means of identification and understanding of the hazards posed by the processes involving regulated substances, in this case, ammonia.



Nature of Business

Growers Ice Company is an industrial refrigeration and ice manufacturing company specializing

in the manufacturing of ice and providing refrigeration for process cooling of fresh fruits and vegetables.

The post-harvest cooling processes that are utilized include vacuum cooling, pressure cooling, hydro cooling, hydro vacuum cooling, ice making and ice injection.

Growers Ice Company also provides refrigeration to NINE (9) facility groupings (addressed sites and buildings) that are used for fresh vegetable processing and cold storage for various customers. Cold Storage facilities are located inside the basic foot print of all nine facilities.

The 1060 Growers Street and the 1055 Merrill Street address do not have a cold room. 1060 Growers Street building was the administrative office for Growers Ice Company. 1055 Merrill Street is currently a receiving/loading dock. The facility legal addresses are as follows:



? 1040 Growers Street (includes Main Engine Room and Condenser Stand located at 1140

   Meeks St.)

? 1055 Merrill Street (Loading and Receiving Dock)

? 1080/1100 Growers Street (Cold Storage and Cooling Yards)

? 1069 Growers Street (Cold Storage and Cooling Yards)

? 1140 Growers Street (Small Freon Cold Room and Processing Building)

? 1060 Growers Street (Old Administrative Office)

? 1166 Growers Street (Cold Storage and Cooling Yards)

? 1067 Merrill Street (Cold Storage and Cooling Yards)

? 1101 Merrill Street (Portable Refrigeration Equipment)

? 1107 Merrill Street (Cold Storage and Cooling Yards)

? 1155 Merrill Street (Cold Storage and Packing Facility and Cooling Yards)



Nature of Hazard

Growers Ice Company, Salinas, CA, produce cooling and shipping facility uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant for their produce pre-cooling, ice making and pressure cooling operations. Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a gas in its natural state and attacks mucous membranes and lung tissue. The gas is pungent and may be suffocating as shortness of breath and labored breathing can develop if inhaled. Prolonged inhalation of high concentrations may cause

bronchitis and or pneumonia, with some residual reduction in pulmonary functions.

Repeated or prolonged contact of high concentrations of ammonia to the skin can cause frostbite, redness, pain and serious skin burn. A Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals Safety Data Sheet (GHS-SDS) (previously MSDS sheets) for

Ammonia is included in Appendix C. Written in English, the GHS-SDS details the chemical properties, health hazards and exposure limits of anhydrous ammonia.



Acutely Hazardous Material Uses

Anhydrous ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the cooling systems. The cooling system consists of a single-stage ammonia refrigeration system with a central plant and a piping loop distributing refrigerant throughout the site.



The system contains approximately 140,000 lb. of ammonia. This is an engineering estimate based on calculations of the system volume. The exact ammonia volume is not known due to the system's age and the fact that the ammonia was not measured into the system. The TPQ for ammonia is 500 lbs.



The main engine room is located at 1040 Growers Street. The main condensers and receivers and the main liquid shutoff valve (King Valve) are located at 1140 Meeks Street. The emergency ammonia high pressure diffusion system consists of a high to low pressure manual relief valve system; a low pressure to high pressure relief valve system, and a water diffuser system located at 1140 Meeks Street. Each system is only to be used in an absolute catastrophic emergency to relieve excess pressure.



There are windsocks located around the main property as an aid for evacuation. A facility-wide computer system manufactured by Andover Corporation controls the temperature of the cold rooms, and operation of evaporators, compressors, and condensers. Safeties are monitored on a real time basis and the computer will test the appropriate responder in the event of an ammonia leak, and related safety hazards. Presently there are three

(3) locations where portable compressor/condenser refrigeration trailer units are tied into the Growers Ice Company main refrigeration piping loop: 1166 Growers St, 1101 Merrill St, and H-10 1069 Growers St.



Equipment located at these addresses is local PLC and computer (Andover) controlled. Operators record and monitor these locations on a shift basis or more frequently as required.

The Andover System monitors on a real time basis and records data as needed and responds to out of parameter conditions.



3. Accidental Release Prevention Program

The Growers Ice Company facility utilizes visual inspections procedures prior to starting and stopping of on-line cooling equipment. This equipment includes compressors, condensers, and evaporation equipment as well as ice makers, vacuum coolers and air handling equipment.



General visual inspections are done throughout the work day as the starting/stopping of the equipment is required.



Inspections identify potential sources of problems and potential releases of ammonia. Equipment corrections are then resolved by on-site personnel, registered engineers and refrigeration contractors as required. Refrigeration equipment will be reviewed for updates and changes when changes occur or when new equipment is brought on site.



As described above, Accidental Release Prevention is a continuing- ongoing process involving system inspection emergency response program and employee hazardous response training is also performed yearly. All new hires are trained in safety and operational safeties specific to the operation of the refrigeration equipment.



Business Response Procedures and Emergency Response Procedures are updated yearly.

Portable equipment, new to the site, is tested for operational safeties at the time of specific installation.



All ammonia refrigeration maintenance and operations personnel are required to be trained and become familiar with the company's Safety and Operational Procedures and Emergency atten

dance records are maintained in the main office. Yearly local community hazardous response training is made available to all employees, refrigeration personnel attend on an availability assigned basis. Records of attendance are in the main office. 



RETA certified operations personnel are trained in safe operating practices of the basic engine rooms and refrigeration systems. Certificates of Achievement copies are maintained in the employee files.



4. Process Hazard Analysis

A thorough review of the system including a "What If" Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed for the 1040 Growers and 1140 Meeks St. facilities on September 13th, 2018. The PHA for all facilities, including 1040 Growers and 1140 Meeks St., and associated equipment (fixed and portable) on the Growers Ice Company Main Property was performed on August 12-13, 2015. Both analyses are included in Appendix D. In addition to visual inspections, code compliance reviews were performed. These reports are included in Seismic Review, Code and Compliance Audits and/or 1124 Abbott St. Growers Ice Company main administrative office. Recommendations for follow-up were made on the basis of criticality to the safe and efficient operation of the system. Equipment corrections and updates were made for those items determined to have the highest potential for offsite releases.



5. Training

All refrigeration personnel are provided with training and information on an ongoing basis.

This training includes but is not limited to Refrigerating Engineers & Technicians Association

(RETA) programs for certification of refrigeration personnel. Growers Ice Company employees are sent to all day seminars and mock drill training on an annual basis and are trained in the following:

? Hazardous communication procedures

? Emergency spills

? Fire extinguisher use

? Ammonia pump down

? Reporting procedures



Training documentation and forms are included in Appendix E.

Immediate supervisors shall provide employees w

ith information and training on hazardous chemicals in their work area at the time of their initial assignment and whenever a new hazard is introduced into their work area.



Employees shall be informed of any operations in work area where hazardous chemicals are present; and, the location and availability of the written hazard communication program, including the required list(s) of hazardous chemicals, and safety data sheets.



Methods and observation that may be used to detect the presence or release of a hazardous chemical in the work area (such as monitoring conducted by the employer, continuously monitoring devices, visual appearance or odor of hazardous chemicals when being released, etc.)

The measures employees can take to protect themselves from these hazards, including specific procedures the employer has implemented to protect employees from exposure to hazardous chemicals, such as appropriate work practices, emergency procedures, and personal protective equipment to be used, and, the details of the hazard communication program developed by the employer, including as explanation of the labeling system and the safety data sheets, and how employees can obtain and use the appropriate hazard information.

6. Updates

As required in Section VI - Updates, refrigeration equipment will be inspected and reviewed periodically and as new equipment becomes operational on-site. When a significant change occurs, the RMP shall be updated to reflect the change. Any management changes must also be updated. This RMP, which includes accident prevention procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system, is maintained on-site, and is also submitted electronically to the EPA

Central Data Exchange (CDX). A copy of the initial registration can be made available upon request.



7. Five-Year Accident History

Growers Ice Company Main Property had NO injuries or accidents reported relating to the release of ammonia refrigerant in the last five years.



Releases of ammonia, shou

ld they occur, will be responded to in accordance with company policy and procedures outlined in the RMP. 



8. Emergency Response Policies

Emergency Response policies are specifically noted in the RMP, with respect to a general overview; on-site personnel provide initial response. On-site personnel will make a preliminary assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response (Growers Ice Company personnel are trained in response). First response may include emergency shut down of equipment, system isolation, controlled operations, such as pump down to prevent or reduce an off-site release.



Local fire and police departments will provide emergency response for a major release event with mutual aid from Growers Ice Company response employees.

Emergency Response notification phone numbers are found in detail in the RMP, reporting Procedures. Detailed phone numbers are updated yearly. Phone Numbers are located in all the

RMP binders and on the face of the Business Response Plan (which contains GIC Emergency response information), Evacuation maps are provided, and windsocks are strategically located on the property to aid in determining prevailing wind and escape routes.



Ammonia detection systems consist of detectors located throughout the property. These detectors are monitored by a computerized monitoring system. An automatic dialing system notifies Growers Ice Company personnel and supervisors depending on the severity of the leak.

A complete location of leak detectors is found in the RMP with appropriate maps and location detail. Ammonia Detector and maps are located in Section II.A - Executive Summary in the map Section.



9. Emergency Response Program

The Growers Ice Company facility has implemented the state and county mandated "Emergency

Response Plan" (a.k.a. "Business Response Plan"). This plan outlines procedures for emergency ammonia release response as well as general facility response. Local community and business notification p

hone numbers are also found in the Emergency Response Plan.



10. Planned Changes to Improve System Safety

Continued response training, safety policy reviews and safety procedure reviews provide "reinforced" safe work practices. Employee's participation through on hands training ultimately makes the workplace and the community a safe place to be.



Being aware of potential problems and responding to a problem prior to emergency status is the preferred method of safety planning. Pro-active mechanical maintenance of the "system"

Include a five-year relief valve change-out program, yearly compressor inspections, bearing Replacements, paint and cleaning of equipment, and general house cleaning.

The "System" is also monitored by a computerized operating system. The system safeties and alarms are recognized and responded to in a timely manner.



Ammonia detectors (strategically placed) are being used in conjunction with automatic paging to key personnel. The "Operator on Duty", received the page, the alarm is noted and responded to, emergency shut down buttons (switches) are strategically located to safely stop the engine room and related equipment. A third party (Sentry Alarm) monitors two-thirds of the main property 24 hours a day seven days a week. In the event of a release of ammonia, ammonia detectors located at several locations will activate and automatic call to the fire department and to responding parties at Growers Ice Company. The remaining Growers Ice Company Main

Property will eventually be monitored as well.



Growers Ice Company has added a diffusion tank piped to an Emergency Control Box. In the event of a dangerous over-pressure situation, this new system will give the operators and fire department the ability to manually relieve pressure into the diffusion tank before ammonia goes into the atmosphere via the pressure relief valves. See section IV.B - Relief System Design for more information regarding the new diffusion system.



There is an int

eractive training and documentation program (Stellar PSM) to better keep tabs on maintenance issues and provide for timely updates that has been put into place, effective January 1, 2018.
